title: 103_hr4512
content: The "Welfare to Work Act of 1994" may be cited as the short title. The Congress acknowledges the importance of the Act. The Congress recognizes the challenges faced by welfare recipients in finding entry-level jobs leading to permanent employment. It is believed that exchanging AFDC payments for work would have greater economic value than traditional welfare programs. Exchanging AFDC payments for work can provide permanent employment to recipients, maximizing economic value and breaking the cycle of welfare dependency. Workfare programs are not a substitute for private sector experience that leads to gainful employment. To break the cycle of welfare dependency, maximize economic value, and promote permanent employment, a one-year tax credit should be given to businesses for hiring AFDC recipients. SEC. 3. REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR HIRING AFDC RECIPIENTS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section providing a refundable credit for businesses employing AFDC recipients. A new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a credit against taxes for qualified first-year wages, with specific percentages based on wage amounts. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a tax credit for qualified first-year wages, based on specific wage amounts ranging from $6,000 to $12,000. Qualified first-year wages are defined as wages for services rendered during the 1-year period starting from the individual's first day of work for the employer. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a tax credit for qualified first-year wages, based on wage amounts from $6,000 to $12,000. Qualified first-year wages are wages for services rendered during the 1-year period starting from the individual's first day of work for the employer. The 1-year period may be reduced by prior service periods with other employers if those wages were considered as qualified first-year wages. Qualified wages are wages paid to qualified former AFDC recipients during the taxable year. The term 'qualified wages' refers to wages paid to qualified former AFDC recipients during the taxable year, as defined in the new section of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'wages' is defined in accordance with section 51(d), excluding paragraph (4) thereof. The term 'wages' for qualified former AFDC recipients is defined in accordance with section 51(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A qualified former AFDC recipient is certified by the designated local agency as a member of a family receiving benefits under a State plan approved under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. A qualified former AFDC recipient is an individual certified by a local agency as a family member receiving benefits under a State plan approved under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. Their wages must make the family ineligible for benefits. This term excludes individuals in targeted groups. The term "qualified former AFDC recipient" refers to an individual who was receiving benefits under title IV of the Social Security Act before their employment with the employer, and whose wages make their family ineligible for benefits. This term excludes individuals in targeted groups. No credit is allowed for wages paid to a qualified former AFDC recipient who replaces an employee terminated without cause. Certain definitions and special rules apply. The section prohibits replacing existing workers to obtain credit for wages paid to qualified former AFDC recipients. Special rules and definitions from section 51 apply. Technical amendments are made to section 280C of the Code.
